newsitem.title: HONG KONG: No impact if Subic deal lost - Hutchison.
newsitem.headline: No impact if Subic deal lost - Hutchison.

text.p: Hutchison Whampoa Ltd said on Friday it had not yet decided whether to re-bid on a container terminal project at Subic Bay in the Philippines but that losing the deal would have no impact on the group.
"We've exhausted all our time and resources for the project," said John Meredith, group managing director at Hutchison Port Holdings. "There comes a point when you have to say enough is enough."

Meredith said the company would have to look at whether it had an interest in placing fresh bids for a project it won twice last year but was forced to reconsider on Thursday when Philippine President Fidel Ramos ordered fresh bidding.
But Meredith said the potential loss of the project would have no effect on Hutchison.
"It has absolutely no impact on the company at all," Meredith said. "It's a pretty insignificant port investment compared to some of the other ones we are looking at."
He declined to speculate on the chances of Hutchison winning back the deal but said re-bidding was technically difficult.
"I think it would be very difficult to re-bid it because everybody knows everybody else's details," he said.
Hutchison unit Hutchison Ports Philippines Ltd was awarded the project last year to develop and operate a container port in Subic Bay.

But on Thursday, Ramos ordered the Subic Bay Metropolitan Authority (SBMA) not to enter into a contract with Hutchison after local competitor International Container Terminal Services (ICTSI) protested.
ICTSI operates the Manila International Container Terminal, which handles 70 percent of container traffic in the country.
"It would look as if it's a situation where the government will continue re-tendering the project until it is won by a local company," Meredith said.
The bidding was marred by too much politics, he said.
"Too many politicians are involved," he said. "There's no other country in the world where we've to explain our bids several times over."
Meredith also questioned the legality of Ramos's move, saying Hutchison had been granted the project by SBMA.
"We are taking advice as to whether legally the president has the power to overthrow the SBMA because SBMA is an autonomous undertaking as far as we know," Meredith said.
